support.p: ff. 1-242, and 259 are parchment; and ff. 243-258 are paper.

foliation.p: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto of each leaf.
Folio 204* is an inserted strip of parchment between f. 203 and f. 204.

ff. [i]-[ii] and [iii] are unfoliated modern paper flyleaves at the beginning and end of the manuscript that have been allocated Roman numerals betweeen square brackets for reference purposes in this electronic edition. Folios 164 and 165 are shown first in their current state and then with the portions along the fore-edge unfolded.

p.formula: Two leaves | 110-2 (9-19th leaves cancelled) 2-178 1812 1910-1 (10th leaf cancelled) 206-3 (4th-6th leaves cancelled) | Two leaves | Four leaves | 21-238 | 24-298 | One leaf | 3016 | One leaf

note.p: This collation deviates from that of M.R. James (1900) and that supplied in the manuscript in that it uses a single continuous number sequence for the manuscript's different parts. It also deviates from the collation by James (1900) in that it states that Quire 1 is a quinternion with 2 (and not 1) cancelled leaves; and that Quire 30 consists of 16 leaves (instead of 18 leaves).

signatures.p: Quire numbers and letters added by a modern hand to the lower outer corners of the first rectos of quires in pencil: 1-20, a-c, 1-7.

note.p: A table of contents for all the manuscript's parts has been added by a 17th-century hand to f. 3r: In hoc volumine continentur.

binding.p: Late 16th- or early 17th-century binding: dark leather over wooden boards with blind-tooled frames and the arms of John Whitgift gold-stamped at the centres of the upper and lower covers; two brass anchor plates on the upper cover and two catch plates at matching height on the lower cover indicate that the binding originally had two straps and clasps. The spine with six raised bands and three paper labels with the printed classmark: B, 14, 19.

provenance.p: Stephan Batman [Stephen Bateman] (1541-1584) Batman [Bateman], Stephan [Stephen], 1541-1584, Church of England clergyman and author: his name inscribed on f. 162v: Batman; purchased the manuscript on 4 October 1584 as is indicated by a note in his hand on f. 3r: this booke cost me 18d the yere anno 1578 / the 4 October his extensive comment, signed S.B. on the spiritual value of a work such as Stimulus Amoris to Protestant readers on f. 67; and his note highlighting a short tract on how to discern wordly and spiritual thoughts on f. 149r: This is a special good notae.

John Whitgift (1530/31?â1604) Whitgift, John, 1530/31?â1604, Master of Trinity College (1567â1577) and archbishop of Canterbury (1583-1604): his heraldic arms impaled with those of the Diocese of Canterbury gold-stamped at the centres of the outsides of the front and rear covers.

history.acquisition: Presented to Trinity College in (?)1604 by John Whitgift (1530/31?â1604) Whitgift, John, 1530/31?â1604, Master of Trinity College (1567â1577) and archbishop of Canterbury (1583-1604): the College's previous and current classmarks R.15.14 (crossed out) and B.14.19 inscribed on the inside of the upper cover; its printed ex libris (with the text: Collegium S.S. et Individuae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigiensi) pasted on the inside of the front cover; its library stamp on ff. 162v, 170r, 191r, 194r, 241r, 243r, and 258r.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS B.14.19, ff. 1-2, 164-165

msItem.title: Commentary on Peter Lombard Sentences [Sententiarum libri IV], fragment: Commentary on Lib. 3 Dis. 19, Qu. 1, Art. 1-4
msItem.author: Thomas Aquinas
msItem.incipit: 1r autem non recipitur influxus in membris diversis sed in membris coniunctis capiti quantumcumque caput in se sit sufficiens ad influendum
msItem.explicit: 2v In quantum .ii. a potestate dyaboli [...] sicut rex regnum
msItem.note: The original order of these four leaves was ff. 164r-164v; ff. 1r-2v; and ff. 165r-165v.

supportDesc.condition: The four leaves have all been heavily cropped, causing loss of the final lines of their double columns. The outer margins of folios 164-165 have been folded into the manuscript.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling. Double columns. At least 44 lines to the page (but the final 1-2 lines have been cropped off on ff. 1-2), writen below top line.

handNote.p: The Chastising of God's Children on ff. 4r-66r was copied by a single hand in a Textualis script with anglicana features.
The Middle English texts on ff. 68r-162v were copied by a single hand in a Textualis script with anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Large (2 lines) initials in blue or red with penwork decoration inside the letter and pen-flourishing extending into the margins in the opposite colour.
A "J"-border in blue and red ink in the inner margin of f. 164r.
Headers consising of Roman numerals and initials in blue and red in the upper margins.
Paraphs alternately in blue or red ink.

note.p: A 17th-century hand has added the title: Stimulus Amoris in brown ink to the upper margin of f. 1r, referring to the contents of the manuscript's second part.

msItem.title: Note on the Stimulus Amoris
msItem.incipit: 67v In mani placis of this Stimulus amoris (this pricke of Love) are veraye good and sounde documents of scripture; and what the reste are . consider the tyme . he is no wyse man . that for the haueng of spiders . scorpions . or any outher noysom thinge in his howse will therefore set the whole howse on fier: for by that meanes, he disfornisheth himselfe of his howse: and so doo men by rashe borneng of auncient Recordes lose the knowledge of muche learnenge there be meanes and wayes . to presarve the good corne by gathering oute the wedes
msItem.note: Full transcription. Copied by Stephan Batman [Stephen Bateman] (1541-1584).

I wole Ã¾ee lere a meditacioun ; compilid is of cristis passioun . And of his modir Ã¾at is so dere ; what peynes Ã¾ei suffrid Ã¾ei mai lere

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written on the lower inner corners of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 31-32 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in a Textualis script.

decoNote.p: Large (2 to 3 lines) blue initials with penwork decoration and pen-flourishing extending into the margins in red ink.
Small (1 line) plain initials in blue or red ink.
Titles and subheadings in red ink.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.

additions.p: The Middle English texts, especially The Chastising of God's Children, feature marginal annotations: 15th-century corrections and 16th-century comments and highlights.

msItem.title: Treatise on the Passion in seven sections
msItem.rubric: 170r Incipiunt dubia notabilia de Passione Christi
msItem.incipit: 170r Christus passus est pro nobis petri 2o Bernardus omelia 22a Christum alloquitur hijs verbis dicens . passio tua Christe . vltimum remedium . singulare refugium . deficiente Sapientia . iusticia non sufficiente . succubentibus meritis peccatoribus et miseris succurit

catchwords.seg: Catchwords inside decorative banderols of dark ink on the inner corners of the lower margins of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 31-39 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The medical recipe added to f. 170r-191r has been copied by a single hand working in a cursive Gothic script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 170r-191r have been copied by a single hand working in a cursive Gothic script.

Headings written in red ink.
Paraphs in red ink.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS B.14.19, ff. 194r-241v

msItem.title: The Lay Folk's Catechism [Expanded Version]
msItem.rubric: 194r An Exposition of the Romish Catakism [Added title]
msItem.incipit: 194r The mayster of sentences in the \ij/ book of and fyrst dystynction there he seyth that Ã¾e souereyn skyl qwy god mad all creaturis in heffne erthe or watyr was hys owyn goodnes qwerefore he wold that summe of theym shuld be comunerys of that blys Ã¾at euyr shal laste
msItem.explicit: 237r-237v In thy body yow shal haue fayrenes swetnes strenthe fredam luste helthe and immortalyte and in Ã¾i sowle thow shalte have wysdom frendechepe acord power worchep souereynte and ioy wyth owtyn ende where to he vs bryng that for vs deyid on the rode tre ihesu cryst goddys sone Amen
msItem.note: The title was added by a 17th-century hand.

msItem.title: Five warnings against swearing by parts of Christ's body
msItem.incipit: 204* recto Gregory. He Ã¾at swereth bi crystes membres . synneth .v. maner wise. i. ffirst . he maktih crystes woundes to blede. / .ij. He makith owr ladi to wepe. / .iij. He makith Ã¾e seintes of hevin sori. / .iiij. He sleith his owne sowle. / .v. He provoktih his own bodi to aschort . and a soudein deth . Quia viri etcaetera . ffor fals and gyleful peple . schul not leve half Ã¾er daies .
msItem.note: Full transcription. This short text is added by a 15th-century hand to The Lay Folk's Catechism. It lists the five negative consequences of swearing (oaths) by parts of Christ's body. The idea that such oaths re-enact Christ's torments in the Passion was commonly expressed in late medieval textual and visual culture (e.g. see Melissa Mohr, Holy Sh*t: A Brief History of Swearing (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), pp. 112-128).

msItem.title: Exposition on the Psalms
msItem.author: Nicholas of Lyra (attributed)
msItem.incipit: 237v Psalterium secundum doctorem de lira est clauis celi et ianua paradisi . pro hoc .ii. celum reseratur et per hoc ad vitam intratur
msItem.explicit: 241r si intima mente per scrusteris et ad medullam intimi intellectus per graciam dei perueneris
msItem.finalRubric: 241r H. Magistri nicholai doctoris de lyra super psalterium

signatures.p: Leaf signatures consisting of combinations of letters A-F and Roman numerals (j-iiij) written in the lower outer corners of the rectos in the first halves of quires (but sometimes cropped off).

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in the lower inner corners of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 31 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The Lay Folk's Catechism (ff. 194r-237v) and the Exposition on the Psalms (ff. 237v-241r) were copied by a single scribe working in an anglicana script with occasional use of the secretary single-compartment a.
The text swearing on folio 204* recto was copied by a a hand in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Large (2 to 3 lines) plain blue initials.
Headings copied in red ink.
Line-fillers consisting of 'stitching' motifs in red ink.
Regula initials higlighted with red ink.
Underlining in red ink.

msItem.note: Contains the personal names of Walter de Brandon and Symon de Hedirset.

msItem.title: Fragment of an account roll
msItem.note: Contains the personal names of Symon de Hederset [also spelled: Hedirset] , Johannis Rolfus, Johannis Curszon, Ricardus de Brandon, Wilhelmus Munping, and G de Brandon; religious titles: the priors of Pentney Priory, Norfolk (Penteneye) and Wymondham Priory, Norfolk (Wymondham) and the vicar of Ketteringham, Norfolk (Keteringham); the aristocratic title of Stanfield, Norfolk (domine de Stanfelde); and the place name of Lingholdelond

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. The dimensions of the original text space, the number of lines to the page, and the position of the first line above or below the top ruled line cannot be established from these fragments. The text is orientated at a 90 degree angle because the account roll's leaves were turned vertically when they were repurposed as flyleaves for this part of the manuscript.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in an anglicana script.

decoDesc.p: This part of the manuscript does not feature any significant decorative features.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS B.14.19, ff. 243r-258r

msItem.title: Litel Tretys on Ã¾e Seven Dedly Synnys
msItem.author: Richard Lavynham
msItem.rubric: 243r A Treatise in the seven deadly sins [added title]
msItem.incipit: 243r Cryst Ã¾at deyed on cros ffor saluacioun of mankend graunt vs grace slyely to askape the sly ensaunple of ffals ensaylyng of Ã¾e fende that we be not for sinne lost in owre last ende amen
msItem.explicit: 258r Also Innocent in lio de miseria condicionis humane . sayth Ã¾at for Ã¾ese synnes god hath drenchyd .v. cytees of whyche the byble spekyth . and for Ã¾is synnes were so horryble and odyous to hym he ne wold commytte Ã¾e poneschyng of hem to ne creature but reseruyd hit to hymself ffro Ã¾ese synnys and from alle oder criste kepe vs throuÈe his grace and take our soules after our deth to hys blysseful place Amen.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 243-258: ? bull's head and ? three mountains.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, inner and outer margins of the frame only. Single columns. 29-35 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a single scribe working in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: 1 large (2 lines) plain red initial on f. 243rwith, inside the letter, a human face in brown ink and penwork decoration in brown ink outside the letter featuring the head of a [?] wolf. These decorative features almost certainly were added at a later stage, most likely by a non-professional.
Large (2 lines) plain red initials.
Headings written in red ink.
Underlining in red ink.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
